newsitem.title: USA: Fed seen refraining from open market operations.
newsitem.headline: Fed seen refraining from open market operations.

text.p: The Federal Reserve is likely to refrain from open market operations on Friday, market sources said.
The Fed injected reserves into the banking system via five-day fixed system repurchase agreements on Thursday.
Analysts interpreted Thursday's operation as an attempt by the central bank to provide the market with sufficient liquidity to span the long Memorial Day Holiday weekend.
By Tuesday, the Fed should get a more accurate estimate on currency demand over the holiday and could choose a longer dated operation -- probably six-day fixed system RPs -- then, analysts said.
With the add need growing in coming weeks, analysts said a permanent injection of reserves could come any time during this period, via an outright purchase of bills or, less likely, a coupon pass.
The Fed has performed a bill pass within two weeks after Memorial Day for six of the last seven years, though the add need this year is not so large as to make one a sure bet, analysts said.
The federal funds rate was trading at 5-5/16 percent, above its 5-1/2 percent target rate, early Friday.
